Award.AwardTitle: A Theoretical and Numerical Study of 2D and 3D Flow over Dynamically Tall Mountain Ranges
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will use a combination of theory and numerical simulation to study the role of stratified air flow over simulated, dynamically varying mountain range heights to determine when the flow must be characterized by fully 3-dimensional flow and when a 2-dimensional framework will suffice to model this flow. The broader impact of this research will serve the Mountain Meteorology community in the areas of aviation and fire safety, as well as micrometeorology of small scale flows.

The proposed research seeks to use a Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) approach to simulate 3-dimensional flow over dynamically tall mountain ranges. Numerical results will be analyzed to determine when and why these flows split. The proposal includes a refinement of earlier theories on these flow splits and potentially the development of a new theoretical basis; particularly for the along-ridge flow variability. Recent theoretical analyses have shown the quantitative connection between blocked flow upstream and asymmetric, supercritical, downslope flow in the lee. Simulations that resolve viscous boundary layers, flow separation and non-hydrostatic shear instabilities suggest these flows separate from the ridge and form an internal hydraulic pump downstream of the separation point. This study will investigate this separation point as a function of dimensionless mountain height and certain thermal characteristics such as the cold pool in the valley between mountain ranges.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a theoretical exploration of the physics processes that control airflow as it encounters topographical obstructions such as mountain ranges and ridgelines. In particular, the project aimed to address from a formal viewpoint, the utility and validity of the often-invoked simplification of the infinite ridge length hypothesis. Making this hypothesis simplifies the analysis significantly, and permitted much of our understanding of topographically controlled mountain overflows to be developed. One outcome of this research was to show the mechanisms and timescales over which finite ridege effects degrade the purely two-dimensional solution and how to correct the theory. A second major outcome of the work was the formulation and analysis of a deceptively simple problem of stratified flow approaching a ridge-like obstruction when the stratification has a sharp density step or inversion. We were able to show that the sharp step can act like virtual topography to the flow aloft and so whether the inversion layer is significantly deflected as it passes over the ridge controls whether or not large amplitude waves are excited aloft. We showed that the deflection of the inversion layer is determined by or not it is entrained in the hydraulically controlled overflow and that this is determined by the height of the inversion. This problem illustrated a dynamical coupling between hydraulic overflows at and in the lee of a topographic obstruction and large amplitude gravity waves well aloft. These aspects of flow over mountains are usually treated as separate phenomena.


The work provides a foundation for linking linear theories of mountain wave excitation with the hydraulic framework of controlled, continuously stratified overflows. Numerical techniques used and refined in the supporting simulations for this work are generally applicable in stratified flow problems, for example in oceanography. The results of this project were disseminated in peer-reviewed journal publications and at national atmospheric conferences. One Ph.D. student was supported. The student received his Ph.D. in 2019 and is continuing his academic career working in geophysical fluid dynamics.
